hedline.hl1: Trillions of Ring Tones, Like Digital Snowflakes

abstract.p: Stephen Wolfram sells system for generating millions of musical ring tones for cellular telephones (S)

block.p: Mathematics and music make strange bedfellows, but that didn't stop Stephen Wolfram. Author of the computer program Mathematica and the book ''A New Kind of Science,'' Mr. Wolfram is now a ring tone impresario.

WolframTones (tones.wolfram.com) are dynamically generated ring tones as unique as a snowflake. Using a basic program that generates a style of music -- rock, swing, classical, rap -- and a set of data, WolframTones creates a new piece of music every time it is run. The core concept in Mr. Wolfram's area of expertise, cellular automata, is that simple rules beget great complexity.
Trillions of dynamically generated ring tones are unique as snowflakes.

Mathematics and music make strange bedfellows, but that didn't stop Stephen Wolfram. Author of the computer program Mathematica and the book ''A New Kind of Science,'' Mr. Wolfram is now a ring tone impresario.

WolframTones (tones.wolfram.com) are dynamically generated ring tones as unique as a snowflake. Using a basic program that generates a style of music -- rock, swing, classical, rap -- and a set of data, WolframTones creates a new piece of music every time it is run. The core concept in Mr. Wolfram's area of expertise, cellular automata, is that simple rules beget great complexity.

The WolframTones system comes with a set of pleasing pieces of music that it tweaks, with increasing complexity, to create trillions of possible ring tone combinations, according to the Web site. The program generates brightly colored fractals that represent different parts of the music.

WolframTones are compatible with almost any cellphone. They are free to generate and cost $2 to download. While the entire enterprise smacks of a million monkeys on a million typewriters, the resulting music is more than acceptable -- and even more inventive than many human compositions.
